title.narrative: Dehytrating fruits, vegetables & herbs in isolated areas of Paraguay

description.narrative:
Pilot project for demonstrative techniques of solar drying.
After getting acquainted to solar plants for processing and drying fruits, vegetables and medicinal plants in Cuba in 2011, the Government of Paraguay has decided to replicate this experience in the country. The project will be financed from outstanding funds (USD 23,001) from a previous project entitled “SF/PAR/96/001 Advisory Servi ces to the Establishment of the Fertilizer Plant in Paraguay” that was carried out by UNIDO in 1996/99.
In the planning and installation of solar plants for drying fruits and vegetables, the pilot stage will include the establishment of a solar dryer mini plant including the entire value chain, from the entrance of fresh products, the respective st eps of preparation, drying, packaging a nd quality control until the final product is packed for sale.
The project will address the agro- value chain through assisting isolated communities in enhancing the value of local production, reducing fruit and vegetable waste and enhancing their conservation times. Through the introduction of a solar dryer mini-plant, this project will permit the advancement of solar technology, the generation of synergies with other value chains and the increased sale of seasonal products.
This project will serve as a demonstration/ pilot project that could be used to gain the support from stakeholders at large for a larger-scale project. with a foreseen the establishment of a number of mini-plants in remote regions cooperating as a cluster. The Ministry stated that the funding for this project should come from the remaining balance of project SFPAR96001, which amounts to USD 25,000); - In February 2013, a mission financed through the UNIDO Industrial Knowledge Bank was fielded to visit several municipalities in Paraguay and assess the feasibility of replicating the project in the country. The mission confirmed the suitability of the country to conduct such pilot project due to abundant fruits, vegetables and herbs as well as good climatic conditions. The locations selected to run the project are Carlos Antonio López and Tembiaporá, where fruits and vegetables are currently grown by local farmers. Due to the lack of technical equipment and knowledge, part of the production is currently wasted and market potential is not fully reached; - The project aims at reducing the waste of fresh fruits, vegetables and herbs in remote rural areas by helping small cooperatives in the transformation of raw materials into value-added products by using techniques of solar drying. The project will include: a) know-how transfer through training workshops; b) pilot project: installation of three solar drying plants; c) training on the method and treatment of finished products. The experience is based on the successful project executed by UNIDO in Cuba in 2010 with the commission of two mini solar dryer plants in Boyero and Banao. The national counterpart of Paraguay visited the facilities in Cuba; - The introduction of solar drying techniques will foster the development of value-added chains in the agribusiness which, in turn, will empower and bring additional income to the recipient communities. Further, the outcomes of this initial pilot preparatory study will be crucial to develop a future project or program of national scope that replicates the experience in all the Paraguayan departments.
